tensorgraph.dataset.mnist module¶

tensorgraph.dataset.mnist.Mnist(binary=True, flatten=False, onehot=True, datadir='.')[source]¶
tensorgraph.dataset.mnist.get_mnist_file(fpath, origin)[source]¶
class tensorgraph.dataset.mnist.open_if_filename(f, mode='r', buffering=-1)[source]¶

Bases: object

tensorgraph.dataset.mnist.read_mnist_images(fn, dtype=None)[source]¶

Read MNIST images from the original ubyte file format. If the dtype provided was boolean, the resulting array will be boolean with True if the corresponding pixel had a value greater than or equal to 128, False otherwise. If the dtype provided was a float or complex dtype, the values will be mapped to the unit interval [0, 1], with pixel values that were 255 in the original unsigned byte representation equal to 1.0.

Parameters:
  • fn (str or object) – Filename/path from which to read labels, or an open file object for the same (will not be closed for you).
  • dtype (str or object, optional) – A NumPy dtype or string that can be converted to one. If unspecified, images will be returned in their original unsigned byte format.
Returns:

images (ndarray, shape (n_images, n_rows, n_cols)) – An image array, with individual examples indexed along the first axis and the image dimensions along the second and third axis.
tensorgraph.dataset.mnist.read_mnist_labels(fn)[source]¶

Read MNIST labels from the original ubyte file format.

Parameters:fn (str or object) – Filename/path from which to read labels, or an open file object for the same (will not be closed for you).
Returns:labels (ndarray, shape (nlabels,)) – A one-dimensional unsigned byte array containing the labels as integers.

tensorgraph.dataset.preprocess module¶

tensorgraph.dataset.preprocess.apply_transform(x, transform_matrix, channel_axis=0, fill_mode='nearest', cval=0.0)[source]¶

Apply the image transformation specified by a matrix.

Parameters:
  • x – 2D numpy array, single image.
  • transform_matrix – Numpy array specifying the geometric transformation.
  • channel_axis – Index of axis for channels in the input tensor.
  • fill_mode – Points outside the boundaries of the input are filled according to the given mode (one of {‘constant’, ‘nearest’, ‘reflect’, ‘wrap’}).
  • cval – Value used for points outside the boundaries of the input if mode=’constant’.
Returns:

The transformed version of the input.
tensorgraph.dataset.preprocess.global_contrast_normalize(X, scale=1.0, min_divisor=1e-08)[source]¶

Subtract mean and normalize by vector norm.

tensorgraph.dataset.preprocess.random_channel_shift(x, intensity, channel_axis=0)[source]¶
tensorgraph.dataset.preprocess.random_rotation(x, rg, row_axis=1, col_axis=2, channel_axis=0, fill_mode='nearest', cval=0.0)[source]¶

Performs a random rotation of a Numpy image tensor.

Parameters:
  • x – Input tensor. Must be 3D.
  • rg – Rotation range, in degrees.
  • row_axis – Index of axis for rows in the input tensor.
  • col_axis – Index of axis for columns in the input tensor.
  • channel_axis – Index of axis for channels in the input tensor.
  • fill_mode – Points outside the boundaries of the input are filled according to the given mode (one of {‘constant’, ‘nearest’, ‘reflect’, ‘wrap’}).
  • cval – Value used for points outside the boundaries of the input if mode=’constant’.
Returns:

Rotated Numpy image tensor.
tensorgraph.dataset.preprocess.random_shear(x, intensity, row_axis=1, col_axis=2, channel_axis=0, fill_mode='nearest', cval=0.0)[source]¶

Performs a random spatial shear of a Numpy image tensor.

Parameters:
  • x – Input tensor. Must be 3D.
  • intensity – Transformation intensity.
  • row_axis – Index of axis for rows in the input tensor.
  • col_axis – Index of axis for columns in the input tensor.
  • channel_axis – Index of axis for channels in the input tensor.
  • fill_mode – Points outside the boundaries of the input are filled according to the given mode (one of {‘constant’, ‘nearest’, ‘reflect’, ‘wrap’}).
  • cval – Value used for points outside the boundaries of the input if mode=’constant’.
Returns:

Sheared Numpy image tensor.
tensorgraph.dataset.preprocess.random_shift(x, wrg, hrg, row_axis=1, col_axis=2, channel_axis=0, fill_mode='nearest', cval=0.0)[source]¶

Performs a random spatial shift of a Numpy image tensor.

Parameters:
  • x – Input tensor. Must be 3D.
  • wrg – Width shift range, as a float fraction of the width.
  • hrg – Height shift range, as a float fraction of the height.
  • row_axis – Index of axis for rows in the input tensor.
  • col_axis – Index of axis for columns in the input tensor.
  • channel_axis – Index of axis for channels in the input tensor.
  • fill_mode – Points outside the boundaries of the input are filled according to the given mode (one of {‘constant’, ‘nearest’, ‘reflect’, ‘wrap’}).
  • cval – Value used for points outside the boundaries of the input if mode=’constant’.
Returns:

Shifted Numpy image tensor.
tensorgraph.dataset.preprocess.random_zoom(x, zoom_range, row_axis=1, col_axis=2, channel_axis=0, fill_mode='nearest', cval=0.0)[source]¶

Performs a random spatial zoom of a Numpy image tensor.

Parameters:
  • x – Input tensor. Must be 3D.
  • zoom_range – Tuple of floats; zoom range for width and height.
  • row_axis – Index of axis for rows in the input tensor.
  • col_axis – Index of axis for columns in the input tensor.
  • channel_axis – Index of axis for channels in the input tensor.
  • fill_mode – Points outside the boundaries of the input are filled according to the given mode (one of {‘constant’, ‘nearest’, ‘reflect’, ‘wrap’}).
  • cval – Value used for points outside the boundaries of the input if mode=’constant’.
Returns:

Zoomed Numpy image tensor.
Raises:

ValueError – if zoom_range isn’t a tuple.

tensorgraph.dataset.preprocess.zca_whiten(train, test, cache=None)[source]¶

Use train set statistics to apply the ZCA whitening transform to both train and test sets.
